body: A modern data scientist is expected to be a catalyst for change in an organisation. This requires not only performing complex data manipulation, but also being able to present the outcomes to senior level decision-makers. In this module we look at how data has changed the way we tell stories.
title: Introduction to data storytelling

_skills.outcome: Explain how data has changed the way we find stories
Explain how data has changed the way we tell stories

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Introduction to data storytelling", adapted from "Introduction to data storytelling" by Open Data Institute, used under CC-BY 4.0.

body: Data is the new raw material that data scientists can use to tell stories and create change. Not all data will be internal to an organisation, so of it can be open data produced by others. This module looks at open data, what it is and why we need it.
title: What is open data?

_skills.outcome: Explain the need for open data

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "What is Open Data?", is a derivative of "What is Open Data?" by European Commission, used under CC-BY-SA 4.0.

body:
Open data has the potential to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

In this module, we explore how governments, businesses and individuals are using open data to create new value.
title: Unlocking value from open data

_skills.outcome: Describe the benefits of working with open data
Describe successful case studies of using and publishing open data

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Unlocking value from open data", is a derivative of "Unlocking value from open data" by European Commission, used under CC-BY-SA 4.0.

body: When working with data, it's critical to understand your rights and your responsibility in ensuring legal and ethical use of data. This module introduces the aspects of law that cover the use of content in different scenarios.
displayTitle: Understanding your rights to use data
title: Understanding your rights to use data

_skills.outcome: Describe how copyright and licensing relate to open data
Identify instances of open licenses and effective application
Explain how copyright exceptions affect the use of data

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Understanding your rights to use data", adapted from "Understanding your rights to use data" by Open Data Institute, used under CC-BY 4.0.

body: To help understand the different types of data and your rights and responsibilities the ODI created the data spectrum. This module introduces the spectrum and the key differences and nuances in open, shared and closed data.
title: The Data Spectrum

body: Regardless of the type of data, the ability to access and gather together data to form a story is the first part of any data science work. This module looks at where you can start to find data and how to unlock cast quantities of data that's hidden on the web.
title: Gathering data

_skills.outcome: Explain the difference between downloadable and hidden data
Describe the benefit of using hidden data

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Gathering data" was originally developed for European Data Science Academy by Open Data Institute, used under CC-BY-SA 4.0.

body: For data to be open, it should be accessible (this usually means being published online) and licensed for anyone to access, use and share. In this module we explore why open data needs to be licensed, how licences unlock the value of open data and what type of licence suits open data.
displayTitle: Why do we need to license?
title: Why do we need to license?

_skills.outcome: Describe how copyright and licensing relate to open data
Identify instances of open licenses and effective application

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Why do we need to license?", is a derivative of "Why do we need to license?" by European Commission, used under CC-BY-SA 4.0.
